pull_request.title: fix(core): `context.type` for around hooks
pull_request.body:
Current implementation is `null` for around hooks (old name: asynchronous hooks used in jsdoc).
I consider this a leftover. `context.type === 'around'` is way more intuitive.

It's also stated in the docs as this PR fixes it:
> `context.type` is a read only property with the hook type (one of `around`, `before`, `after` or `error`).

https://dove.feathersjs.com/api/hooks.html#context-type

comment.body: So over the last little while we realised that all the query sanitisation is just a complicated and convoluted way of doing query schema validation which is exactly what we'd like to encourage in the future. So https://github.com/feathersjs/feathers/pull/2906 implemented a change that skips query sanitisation if you already validated your query against a schema which will be the recommended way going forward.

pull_request.title: feat(cli): Use separate patch schema and types
pull_request.body: This pull request adds the patch types added in https://github.com/feathersjs/feathers/pull/2906 to the generated application. It adds separate create and patch validators and resolvers which keeps them more flexible. It also disables the `update` method by default since it does not appear to be used or provides anything `patch` doesn't already allow (you can `patch` the whole record).

issue.title: v5 AuthenticationService create hooks reversed order
issue.body:
I recently began updating a feathers v4 app to v5 in anticipation of it's release. So far the upgrade has been pretty smooth! the one issue I ran into and believe is a bug is how the AuthenticationService class sets up it's hooks

V5

https://github.com/feathersjs/feathers/blob/4ff1ed084eb2b2cb687de27a28c96a0dad4530b7/packages/authentication/src/service.ts#L45

V4
https://github.com/feathersjs/feathers/blob/d0e9600002975296ab8de926acd317d0a73fce5c/packages/authentication/src/service.ts#L172

It looks like in V5 these are now using @feathersjs/hooks directly and appear to run in reverse order

basically what appears to happen is the app.login event is emitted before the user entity is added to connection object. this means the "user" will never get assigned to the authenticated clients channel

### Expected behavior

the user object should be available on the connection object in the app.login event handler

### Actual behavior

user is not available on the connection object in the app.login event handler. so it is never added to the "authenticated" channel.

### System configuration
----

**Module versions** (especially the part that's not working):
5.0.0-pre.33

**NodeJS version**:
v17.2.0

**Operating System**:
arch linux

**Browser Version**:
---- 
**React Native Version**:
---- 
**Module Loader**:
----

issue.title: memory - Allow custom sift options
issue.body:
Sift allows a second argument of options which can include custom operators, etc. Similar to other database adapters that accept some database config, I think we should allows this adapter to accept `params.matcher`. Then Sift configuration can happen on each call.

I am aware that the service options takes a `matcher` option and I can use a custom Sift here. But that is statically set and cannot change per service call.

This should be as simple as updating https://github.com/feathersjs/feathers/blob/9f712bf5694ceb7b47e3c7ab68a30c8a8cec3faa/packages/memory/src/index.ts#L91
to 
```js
const matcher = this.options.matcher(query, params.matcher)
```

comment.body: Sounds good to me, I'd merge a PR with those changes and according documentation updates.

issue.body:
Has the [documentation](https://dove.feathersjs.com/api/configuration.html#configuration-validation) for configuration been updated to latest TypeBox? 


The latest ``npm create...`` (v.33) gave me not the file as in the docs, but  this ``configuration.ts``:
```ts
import { Type, getValidator, defaultAppConfiguration } from '@feathersjs/typebox'
import type { Static } from '@feathersjs/typebox'

import { dataValidator } from './validators'

export const configurationSchema = Type.Intersect([
  defaultAppConfiguration,
  Type.Object({
    host: Type.String(),
    port: Type.Number(),
    public: Type.String()
  })
])

export type ApplicationConfiguration = Static<typeof configurationSchema>

export const configurationValidator = getValidator(configurationSchema, dataValidator)

```

Problem is that I am struggling to use ``.env`` and  change default ``mongodb`` string into an object

    "username": "MONGO_INITDB_ROOT_USERNAME",
    "password": "MONGO_INITDB_ROOT_PASSWORD"

```

```ts
// src/mongodb.ts
  const mngDef = app.get('mongodb') as any

```

issue.title: [dove] how to keep value across services and hooks
issue.body:
In file channels upon `"on connection" `event, a user needs to join his own channels using his Id. So I call a service to fetch complete user profile from db by Id, then join him properly.

Question:

1. To minimize db call, the result of fetching user will be used later in hooks & services; where can I keep it so I can access it later? _(as recommended, app.set is not a choice)_

2. The argument given for "on connection" event is **connection** object (Partial<Params>), the argument given for services is full **params**, for hooks is **context**; I read somewhere that this is by-design. Are they separated and exclusive? Is it possible to access the same app (feathers) object? 

Thank you

comment.body: A user won't be available until in the `login` event. The `connection` even always happens before that.

issue.title: [dove] how to keep value across services and hooks
issue.body:
In file channels upon `"on connection" `event, a user needs to join his own channels using his Id. So I call a service to fetch complete user profile from db by Id, then join him properly.

Question:

1. To minimize db call, the result of fetching user will be used later in hooks & services; where can I keep it so I can access it later? _(as recommended, app.set is not a choice)_

2. The argument given for "on connection" event is **connection** object (Partial<Params>), the argument given for services is full **params**, for hooks is **context**; I read somewhere that this is by-design. Are they separated and exclusive? Is it possible to access the same app (feathers) object? 

Thank you

comment.body: The `params` object is the same across all hooks and the service call. You can add any value to it at any time in the call. Note that it'll have to be passed explicitly to other service calls.

issue.title: fix(feathers): `contex.type` for around hooks
issue.body:
Current implementation is `null` for around hooks (old name: asynchronous hooks used in jsdoc).
I consider this a leftover. `context.type === 'around'` is way more intuitive.

It's also stated in the docs as this PR fixes it:
> `context.type` is a read only property with the hook type (one of `around`, `before`, `after` or `error`).

https://dove.feathersjs.com/api/hooks.html#context-type

comment.body: Agreed on the separation. The context of `@feathersjs/hooks` already has some additional properties (like `method`, `result` and `arguments` - see https://github.com/feathersjs/hooks#hook-context) so adding a `type` (which it already does for the `regular` wrapper) wouldn't be against the design though.

issue.title: fix(feathers): `contex.type` for around hooks
issue.body:
Current implementation is `null` for around hooks (old name: asynchronous hooks used in jsdoc).
I consider this a leftover. `context.type === 'around'` is way more intuitive.

It's also stated in the docs as this PR fixes it:
> `context.type` is a read only property with the hook type (one of `around`, `before`, `after` or `error`).

https://dove.feathersjs.com/api/hooks.html#context-type

comment.body: People were still looking for a general purpose traditional hook wrapper (see https://github.com/feathersjs/hooks#regular-hooks) so @marshallswain voted for having it in there. The terminology has gone through a bit of a process so maybe it should actually be updated in that repository from "async hooks" to "around hooks" as well.

issue.title: idea: add vscode-plugin with file preview
issue.body: Add a plugin for VSCode to preview a template file side by side with example context. Similar to markdown or html where you can have side by side the origin and the rendered content. It would be really nice to have this for various template files. Something like this: For markdown and html files, it would also be pretty nice, to see the rendered file, not only the source code (maybe toggable)

comment.body: This would be pretty great, especially since there already is a plugin for highlighting code in template string. The only tricky part is that the context objects can get pretty complicated, e.g. in the Feathers CLI they are dependent on the generated app package.json, current working directory and possibly even other files. On the other hand, not all context properties are always used in a template.

pull_request.title: feat(adapter): Add patch data type to adapters and refactor AdapterBase usage
pull_request.body:
This pull request adds the ability to use a `PatchData` type in the adapters which may be different than the usual data type.

It also refactors the `AdapterBase` to remove the confusing and convoluted `$` prefixed service methods. Instead an adapter just implements the underscored service methods as before. While for the top level usage backwards compatible this may be a breaking change in some hopefully still uncommon instances but it reduces a lot of the complexity when implementing a database adapter.

You can still extend directly from the adapter class to implement the actual service methods with your own signatures and return types. This will circumvent the legacy query sanitisation which is now done with query schemas anyway.

issue.title: v5 AuthenticationService create hooks reversed order
issue.body:
I recently began updating a feathers v4 app to v5 in anticipation of it's release. So far the upgrade has been pretty smooth! the one issue I ran into and believe is a bug is how the AuthenticationService class sets up it's hooks

V5

https://github.com/feathersjs/feathers/blob/4ff1ed084eb2b2cb687de27a28c96a0dad4530b7/packages/authentication/src/service.ts#L45

V4
https://github.com/feathersjs/feathers/blob/d0e9600002975296ab8de926acd317d0a73fce5c/packages/authentication/src/service.ts#L172

It looks like in V5 these are now using @feathersjs/hooks directly and appear to run in reverse order

basically what appears to happen is the app.login event is emitted before the user entity is added to connection object. this means the "user" will never get assigned to the authenticated clients channel

### Expected behavior

the user object should be available on the connection object in the app.login event handler

### Actual behavior

user is not available on the connection object in the app.login event handler. so it is never added to the "authenticated" channel.

### System configuration
----

**Module versions** (especially the part that's not working):
5.0.0-pre.33

**NodeJS version**:
v17.2.0

**Operating System**:
arch linux

**Browser Version**:
---- 
**React Native Version**:
---- 
**Module Loader**:
----

comment.body: Oh sorry, my bad, I get it now. The order _should_ be reversed because of what I just explained but they are still in the same order which is causing the problem you are describing.

issue.title: feat(adapter): Add patch data type to adapters and refactor AdapterBase usage
issue.body:
This pull request adds the ability to use a `PatchData` type in the adapters which may be different than the usual data type.

It also refactors the `AdapterBase` to remove the confusing and convoluted `$` prefixed service methods. Instead an adapter just implements the underscored service methods as before. While for the top level usage backwards compatible this may be a breaking change in some hopefully still uncommon instances but it reduces a lot of the complexity when implementing a database adapter.

You can still extend directly from the adapter class to implement the actual service methods with your own signatures and return types. This will circumvent the legacy query sanitisation which is now done with query schemas anyway.

issue.title: Suggestion: resultResolver should not resolve properties if they are not present in $select when $select is specified
issue.body:
Currently all properties defined in resultResolver are resolved. Even if we do not explicitly specify them in $select.

As an example:
In a service a field exists, not in the database, but is calculated in the resultResolver. If we now query this service and select only some fields via $select and this field is not included, it is currently resolved and is thus unintentionally in the result. Unfortunately it is currently not possible to access `context.params.query.$select` in the resolver function, since it no longer exists at this point. Apart from this, an additional unnecessary function call is made here.

Disadvantage is of course at this point that this field would have to be filtered out in the service with the database query if the field is however explicitly selected with $select.

pull_request.title: feat(core): Allow to enable internal service methods
pull_request.body:
This pull request allows to list service methods that should be enabled with hooks and send events but not be available to external clients when registering a service:

```ts
app.use('myservice', new MyService(), {
  methods: ['get', 'find'], // Only get and find available externally
  serviceMethods: ['create', 'update'] // Should have hooks and send events but not be evailable
})
```

It also tightens up the types for both the `methods` and `serviceMethods` options to only allow methods that are available on the service.

It adds separate create and patch validators and resolvers which keeps them more flexible. It also disables the `update` method by default since it does not appear to be used or provides anything `patch` doesn't already allow (you can `patch` the whole record).

issue.title: v5 AuthenticationService create hooks reversed order
issue.body:
I recently began updating a feathers v4 app to v5 in anticipation of it's release. So far the upgrade has been pretty smooth! the one issue I ran into and believe is a bug is how the AuthenticationService class sets up it's hooks

V5

https://github.com/feathersjs/feathers/blob/4ff1ed084eb2b2cb687de27a28c96a0dad4530b7/packages/authentication/src/service.ts#L45

V4
https://github.com/feathersjs/feathers/blob/d0e9600002975296ab8de926acd317d0a73fce5c/packages/authentication/src/service.ts#L172

It looks like in V5 these are now using @feathersjs/hooks directly and appear to run in reverse order

basically what appears to happen is the app.login event is emitted before the user entity is added to connection object. this means the "user" will never get assigned to the authenticated clients channel

### Expected behavior

the user object should be available on the connection object in the app.login event handler

### Actual behavior

user is not available on the connection object in the app.login event handler. so it is never added to the "authenticated" channel.

### System configuration
----

**Module versions** (especially the part that's not working):
5.0.0-pre.33

**NodeJS version**:
v17.2.0

**Operating System**:
arch linux

**Browser Version**:
---- 
**React Native Version**:
---- 
**Module Loader**:
----

issue.title: memory - Allow custom sift options
issue.body:
Sift allows a second argument of options which can include custom operators, etc. Similar to other database adapters that accept some database config, I think we should allows this adapter to accept `params.matcher`. Then Sift configuration can happen on each call.

I am aware that the service options takes a `matcher` option and I can use a custom Sift here. But that is statically set and cannot change per service call.

This should be as simple as updating https://github.com/feathersjs/feathers/blob/9f712bf5694ceb7b47e3c7ab68a30c8a8cec3faa/packages/memory/src/index.ts#L91
to 
```js
const matcher = this.options.matcher(query, params.matcher)
```

comment.body: Sounds good to me, I'd merge a PR with those changes and according documentation updates.

The latest ``npm create...`` (v.33) gave me not the file as in the docs, but  this ``configuration.ts``:
```ts
import { Type, getValidator, defaultAppConfiguration } from '@feathersjs/typebox'
import type { Static } from '@feathersjs/typebox'

import { dataValidator } from './validators'

export const configurationSchema = Type.Intersect([
  defaultAppConfiguration,
  Type.Object({
    host: Type.String(),
    port: Type.Number(),
    public: Type.String()

])

export type ApplicationConfiguration = Static<typeof configurationSchema>

export const configurationValidator = getValidator(configurationSchema, dataValidator)

issue.title: [dove] how to keep value across services and hooks
issue.body:
In file channels upon `"on connection" `event, a user needs to join his own channels using his Id. So I call a service to fetch complete user profile from db by Id, then join him properly.

Question:

1. To minimize db call, the result of fetching user will be used later in hooks & services; where can I keep it so I can access it later? _(as recommended, app.set is not a choice)_

2. The argument given for "on connection" event is **connection** object (Partial<Params>), the argument given for services is full **params**, for hooks is **context**; I read somewhere that this is by-design. Are they separated and exclusive? Is it possible to access the same app (feathers) object? 

Thank you

comment.body: A user won't be available until in the `login` event. The `connection` even always happens before that.

comment.body: The `params` object is the same across all hooks and the service call. You can add any value to it at any time in the call. Note that it'll have to be passed explicitly to other service calls.

issue.title: fix(feathers): `contex.type` for around hooks
issue.body:
Current implementation is `null` for around hooks (old name: asynchronous hooks used in jsdoc).
I consider this a leftover. `context.type === 'around'` is way more intuitive.

It's also stated in the docs as this PR fixes it:
> `context.type` is a read only property with the hook type (one of `around`, `before`, `after` or `error`).

https://dove.feathersjs.com/api/hooks.html#context-type

comment.body: Agreed on the separation. The context of `@feathersjs/hooks` already has some additional properties (like `method`, `result` and `arguments` - see https://github.com/feathersjs/hooks#hook-context) so adding a `type` (which it already does for the `regular` wrapper) wouldn't be against the design though.

issue.title: fix(feathers): `contex.type` for around hooks

https://dove.feathersjs.com/api/hooks.html#context-type

comment.body: People were still looking for a general purpose traditional hook wrapper (see https://github.com/feathersjs/hooks#regular-hooks) so @marshallswain voted for having it in there. The terminology has gone through a bit of a process so maybe it should actually be updated in that repository from "async hooks" to "around hooks" as well.

pull_request.title: feat(adapter): Add patch data type to adapters and refactor AdapterBase usage
pull_request.body:
This pull request adds the ability to use a `PatchData` type in the adapters which may be different than the usual data type.

It also refactors the `AdapterBase` to remove the confusing and convoluted `$` prefixed service methods. Instead an adapter just implements the underscored service methods as before. While for the top level usage backwards compatible this may be a breaking change in some hopefully still uncommon instances but it reduces a lot of the complexity when implementing a database adapter.

You can still extend directly from the adapter class to implement the actual service methods with your own signatures and return types. This will circumvent the legacy query sanitisation which is now done with query schemas anyway.

issue.title: v5 AuthenticationService create hooks reversed order
issue.body:
I recently began updating a feathers v4 app to v5 in anticipation of it's release. So far the upgrade has been pretty smooth! the one issue I ran into and believe is a bug is how the AuthenticationService class sets up it's hooks

V5

https://github.com/feathersjs/feathers/blob/4ff1ed084eb2b2cb687de27a28c96a0dad4530b7/packages/authentication/src/service.ts#L45

V4
https://github.com/feathersjs/feathers/blob/d0e9600002975296ab8de926acd317d0a73fce5c/packages/authentication/src/service.ts#L172

It looks like in V5 these are now using @feathersjs/hooks directly and appear to run in reverse order

basically what appears to happen is the app.login event is emitted before the user entity is added to connection object. this means the "user" will never get assigned to the authenticated clients channel

### Expected behavior

the user object should be available on the connection object in the app.login event handler

### Actual behavior

user is not available on the connection object in the app.login event handler. so it is never added to the "authenticated" channel.

### System configuration
----

**Module versions** (especially the part that's not working):
5.0.0-pre.33

**NodeJS version**:
v17.2.0

**Operating System**:
arch linux

**Browser Version**:
---- 
**React Native Version**:
---- 
**Module Loader**:
----

comment.body: Oh sorry, my bad, I get it now. The order _should_ be reversed because of what I just explained but they are still in the same order which is causing the problem you are describing.

issue.title: Suggestion: resultResolver should not resolve properties if they are not present in $select when $select is specified
issue.body:
Currently all properties defined in resultResolver are resolved. Even if we do not explicitly specify them in $select.

As an example:
In a service a field exists, not in the database, but is calculated in the resultResolver. If we now query this service and select only some fields via $select and this field is not included, it is currently resolved and is thus unintentionally in the result. Unfortunately it is currently not possible to access `context.params.query.$select` in the resolver function, since it no longer exists at this point. Apart from this, an additional unnecessary function call is made here.

Disadvantage is of course at this point that this field would have to be filtered out in the service with the database query if the field is however explicitly selected with $select.

pull_request.title: feat(core): Allow to enable internal service methods
pull_request.body:
This pull request allows to list service methods that should be enabled with hooks and send events but not be available to external clients when registering a service:

```ts
app.use('myservice', new MyService(), {
  methods: ['get', 'find'], // Only get and find available externally
  serviceMethods: ['create', 'update'] // Should have hooks and send events but not be evailable
})
```

It also tightens up the types for both the `methods` and `serviceMethods` options to only allow methods that are available on the service.

issue.title: adapter-commons/filter-query.ts:cleanQuery whitelist test
issue.body:
I've added additional known operators to whitelist option for feathers-sequelize, but cleanQuery is also failing things like '"$primaryLocation.city$".

Is it reasonable that sequelize field expressions are blacklisted by default, or can you test for $ at start and end and allow, or have that as another option along whitelist,
or support regexp values in whitelist?

comment.body: So over the last little while we realised that all the query sanitisation is just a complicated and convoluted way of doing query schema validation which is exactly what we'd like to encourage in the future. So https://github.com/feathersjs/feathers/pull/2906 implemented a change that skips query sanitisation if you already validated your query against a schema which will be the recommended way going forward.

pull_request.title: feat(cli): Use separate patch schema and types
pull_request.body: This pull request adds the patch types added in https://github.com/feathersjs/feathers/pull/2906 to the generated application. It adds separate create and patch validators and resolvers which keeps them more flexible. It also disables the `update` method by default since it does not appear to be used or provides anything `patch` doesn't already allow (you can `patch` the whole record).

issue.title: v5 AuthenticationService create hooks reversed order
issue.body:
I recently began updating a feathers v4 app to v5 in anticipation of it's release. So far the upgrade has been pretty smooth! the one issue I ran into and believe is a bug is how the AuthenticationService class sets up it's hooks

V5

https://github.com/feathersjs/feathers/blob/4ff1ed084eb2b2cb687de27a28c96a0dad4530b7/packages/authentication/src/service.ts#L45

V4
https://github.com/feathersjs/feathers/blob/d0e9600002975296ab8de926acd317d0a73fce5c/packages/authentication/src/service.ts#L172

It looks like in V5 these are now using @feathersjs/hooks directly and appear to run in reverse order

basically what appears to happen is the app.login event is emitted before the user entity is added to connection object. this means the "user" will never get assigned to the authenticated clients channel

### Expected behavior

the user object should be available on the connection object in the app.login event handler

### Actual behavior

user is not available on the connection object in the app.login event handler. so it is never added to the "authenticated" channel.

### System configuration
----

**Module versions** (especially the part that's not working):
5.0.0-pre.33

**NodeJS version**:
v17.2.0

**Operating System**:
arch linux

**Browser Version**:
---- 
**React Native Version**:
---- 
**Module Loader**:
----

issue.title: memory - Allow custom sift options
issue.body:
Sift allows a second argument of options which can include custom operators, etc. Similar to other database adapters that accept some database config, I think we should allows this adapter to accept `params.matcher`. Then Sift configuration can happen on each call.

I am aware that the service options takes a `matcher` option and I can use a custom Sift here. But that is statically set and cannot change per service call.

This should be as simple as updating https://github.com/feathersjs/feathers/blob/9f712bf5694ceb7b47e3c7ab68a30c8a8cec3faa/packages/memory/src/index.ts#L91
to 
```js
const matcher = this.options.matcher(query, params.matcher)
```

comment.body: Sounds good to me, I'd merge a PR with those changes and according documentation updates.

issue.title: Documentation for Configuration, TypeBox and .dotenv
issue.body:
Has the [documentation](https://dove.feathersjs.com/api/configuration.html#configuration-validation) for configuration been updated to latest TypeBox? 


The latest ``npm create...`` (v.33) gave me not the file as in the docs, but  this ``configuration.ts``:
```ts
import { Type, getValidator, defaultAppConfiguration } from '@feathersjs/typebox'
import type { Static } from '@feathersjs/typebox'

import { dataValidator } from './validators'

export const configurationSchema = Type.Intersect([
  defaultAppConfiguration,
  Type.Object({
    host: Type.String(),
    port: Type.Number(),
    public: Type.String()
  })
])

export type ApplicationConfiguration = Static<typeof configurationSchema>

export const configurationValidator = getValidator(configurationSchema, dataValidator)

```

Problem is that I am struggling to use ``.env`` and  change default ``mongodb`` string into an object
 ``/config/default.json``:
```json
 "mongodb": {
    "host": "localhost:27017"
  },
```

 ``/config/custom-environment-variables.json``:
```json
 "mongodb": {
    "database": "MONGO_INITDB_DATABASE",
    "username": "MONGO_INITDB_ROOT_USERNAME",
    "password": "MONGO_INITDB_ROOT_PASSWORD"
 },
```

```ts
// src/mongodb.ts
  const mngDef = app.get('mongodb') as any
  console.log(mngDef.username) // gives: undefined and validation error
```

issue.title: [dove] how to keep value across services and hooks
issue.body:
In file channels upon `"on connection" `event, a user needs to join his own channels using his Id. So I call a service to fetch complete user profile from db by Id, then join him properly.

Question:

1. To minimize db call, the result of fetching user will be used later in hooks & services; where can I keep it so I can access it later? _(as recommended, app.set is not a choice)_

2. The argument given for "on connection" event is **connection** object (Partial<Params>), the argument given for services is full **params**, for hooks is **context**; I read somewhere that this is by-design. Are they separated and exclusive? Is it possible to access the same app (feathers) object? 

Thank you

comment.body: A user won't be available until in the `login` event. The `connection` even always happens before that.

issue.title: [dove] how to keep value across services and hooks
issue.body:
In file channels upon `"on connection" `event, a user needs to join his own channels using his Id. So I call a service to fetch complete user profile from db by Id, then join him properly.

Question:

1. To minimize db call, the result of fetching user will be used later in hooks & services; where can I keep it so I can access it later? _(as recommended, app.set is not a choice)_

2. The argument given for "on connection" event is **connection** object (Partial<Params>), the argument given for services is full **params**, for hooks is **context**; I read somewhere that this is by-design. Are they separated and exclusive? Is it possible to access the same app (feathers) object? 

Thank you

comment.body: The `params` object is the same across all hooks and the service call. You can add any value to it at any time in the call. Note that it'll have to be passed explicitly to other service calls.

issue.title: fix(feathers): `contex.type` for around hooks
issue.body:
Current implementation is `null` for around hooks (old name: asynchronous hooks used in jsdoc).
I consider this a leftover. `context.type === 'around'` is way more intuitive.

It's also stated in the docs as this PR fixes it:
> `context.type` is a read only property with the hook type (one of `around`, `before`, `after` or `error`).

https://dove.feathersjs.com/api/hooks.html#context-type

comment.body: Agreed on the separation. The context of `@feathersjs/hooks` already has some additional properties (like `method`, `result` and `arguments` - see https://github.com/feathersjs/hooks#hook-context) so adding a `type` (which it already does for the `regular` wrapper) wouldn't be against the design though.

issue.title: fix(feathers): `contex.type` for around hooks
issue.body:
Current implementation is `null` for around hooks (old name: asynchronous hooks used in jsdoc).
I consider this a leftover. `context.type === 'around'` is way more intuitive.

It's also stated in the docs as this PR fixes it:
> `context.type` is a read only property with the hook type (one of `around`, `before`, `after` or `error`).

https://dove.feathersjs.com/api/hooks.html#context-type

comment.body: People were still looking for a general purpose traditional hook wrapper (see https://github.com/feathersjs/hooks#regular-hooks) so @marshallswain voted for having it in there. The terminology has gone through a bit of a process so maybe it should actually be updated in that repository from "async hooks" to "around hooks" as well.

issue.title: idea: add vscode-plugin with file preview
issue.body: Add a plugin for VSCode to preview a template file side by side with example context. Similar to markdown or html where you can have side by side the origin and the rendered content. It would be really nice to have this for various template files. Something like this: For markdown and html files, it would also be pretty nice, to see the rendered file, not only the source code (maybe toggable)

comment.body: This would be pretty great, especially since there already is a plugin for highlighting code in template string. The only tricky part is that the context objects can get pretty complicated, e.g. in the Feathers CLI they are dependent on the generated app package.json, current working directory and possibly even other files. On the other hand, not all context properties are always used in a template.

pull_request.title: feat(adapter): Add patch data type to adapters and refactor AdapterBase usage
pull_request.body:
This pull request adds the ability to use a `PatchData` type in the adapters which may be different than the usual data type.

It also refactors the `AdapterBase` to remove the confusing and convoluted `$` prefixed service methods. Instead an adapter just implements the underscored service methods as before. While for the top level usage backwards compatible this may be a breaking change in some hopefully still uncommon instances but it reduces a lot of the complexity when implementing a database adapter.

You can still extend directly from the adapter class to implement the actual service methods with your own signatures and return types. This will circumvent the legacy query sanitisation which is now done with query schemas anyway.

issue.title: v5 AuthenticationService create hooks reversed order
issue.body:
I recently began updating a feathers v4 app to v5 in anticipation of it's release. So far the upgrade has been pretty smooth! the one issue I ran into and believe is a bug is how the AuthenticationService class sets up it's hooks

V5

https://github.com/feathersjs/feathers/blob/4ff1ed084eb2b2cb687de27a28c96a0dad4530b7/packages/authentication/src/service.ts#L45

V4
https://github.com/feathersjs/feathers/blob/d0e9600002975296ab8de926acd317d0a73fce5c/packages/authentication/src/service.ts#L172

It looks like in V5 these are now using @feathersjs/hooks directly and appear to run in reverse order

basically what appears to happen is the app.login event is emitted before the user entity is added to connection object. this means the "user" will never get assigned to the authenticated clients channel

### Expected behavior

the user object should be available on the connection object in the app.login event handler

### Actual behavior

user is not available on the connection object in the app.login event handler. so it is never added to the "authenticated" channel.

### System configuration
----

**Module versions** (especially the part that's not working):
5.0.0-pre.33

**NodeJS version**:
v17.2.0

**Operating System**:
arch linux

**Browser Version**:
---- 
**React Native Version**:
---- 
**Module Loader**:
----

comment.body: Oh sorry, my bad, I get it now. The order _should_ be reversed because of what I just explained but they are still in the same order which is causing the problem you are describing.

It now also throws a more descriptive error when trying to create a query syntax helper for a non-primitive type which is currently not possible.

issue.title: feat(adapter): Add patch data type to adapters and refactor AdapterBase usage
issue.body:
This pull request adds the ability to use a `PatchData` type in the adapters which may be different than the usual data type.

It also refactors the `AdapterBase` to remove the confusing and convoluted `$` prefixed service methods. Instead an adapter just implements the underscored service methods as before. While for the top level usage backwards compatible this may be a breaking change in some hopefully still uncommon instances but it reduces a lot of the complexity when implementing a database adapter.

You can still extend directly from the adapter class to implement the actual service methods with your own signatures and return types. This will circumvent the legacy query sanitisation which is now done with query schemas anyway.

comment.body: I just added it in https://github.com/feathersjs/feathers/pull/2906/files#diff-686d31b4a5c93b9ab0ae6b60817ed194db3eccfaff344cfec6382f2439ce1e03R100

pull_request.body:
### Summary

(If you have not already please refer to the contributing guideline as [described
here](https://github.com/feathersjs/feathers/blob/dove/.github/contributing.md#pull-requests))

- [X] Tell us about the problem your pull request is solving.
- [X] Are there any open issues that are related to this? No
- [X] Is this PR dependent on PRs in other repos? No

If so, please mention them to keep the conversations linked together.

### Other Information

This PR solves the following issues:

- Usage of double Partial which results in the type `Partial<Partial<T>>`
- Corrects return of $find in the test fixture of adapter-commons
- Corrects return of $update in the test fixture of adapter-commons
- Changes `never[]` to `any[]` in service.test.ts of adapter-commons to prevent type error

### Feedback

It is hard to find the contributing.md file. I suggest adding a link in the README.md for better visibility.

issue.title: Suggestion: resultResolver should not resolve properties if they are not present in $select when $select is specified
issue.body:
Currently all properties defined in resultResolver are resolved. Even if we do not explicitly specify them in $select.

As an example:
In a service a field exists, not in the database, but is calculated in the resultResolver. If we now query this service and select only some fields via $select and this field is not included, it is currently resolved and is thus unintentionally in the result. Unfortunately it is currently not possible to access `context.params.query.$select` in the resolver function, since it no longer exists at this point. Apart from this, an additional unnecessary function call is made here.

Disadvantage is of course at this point that this field would have to be filtered out in the service with the database query if the field is however explicitly selected with $select.

pull_request.title: feat(core): Allow to enable internal service methods
pull_request.body:
This pull request allows to list service methods that should be enabled with hooks and send events but not be available to external clients when registering a service:

```ts
app.use('myservice', new MyService(), {
  methods: ['get', 'find'], // Only get and find available externally
  serviceMethods: ['create', 'update'] // Should have hooks and send events but not be evailable
})
```

It also tightens up the types for both the `methods` and `serviceMethods` options to only allow methods that are available on the service.
